qas.question: Who has said the Sanskrit is dead?
According to Pollock, how is Sanskrit solely used?
What is Sanskrit not  able to express?
How is Sanskrit limited in it function towards ideas?
What did Andrew Pollock say of Sanskrit?
What 18th century commentary did Caturdhara's speak about?
Sanskrit is not often used in what forms of creative uses?
Where is Sanskrit no longer used?

plausible_answers.text: to express the changing forms of subjectivity

qas.question: In what way has Sanskrit adapted in the modern age?

context: <a0_0>Sheldon Pollock<a0_0/> argues that "most observers would agree that, in some crucial way, <b5_0>Sanskrit is dead<b5_0/>".:393 Pollock has further argued that, while Sanskrit continued to be used in <a1_0><b8_0>literary cultures<a1_0/> in India<b8_0/>, it was never adapted <b9_0>to express the changing forms of subjectivity<b9_0/> and sociality as embodied and conceptualised in <a2_0>the modern age<a2_0/>.:416 Instead, it was reduced to "reinscription and <a3_0>restatements<a3_0/>" of ideas already explored, and any creativity was restricted to <a4_0><b7_0>hymns<a4_0/> and verses<b7_0/>.:398 A notable exception are the military references of Nīlakaṇṭha Caturdhara's 17th-century commentary on the <b6_0>Mahābhārata<b6_0/>.
